Award.AwardTitle: Pursuing the Nucleus: Experimental, Theoretical, and Analytical Investigations of Bubble and Crystal Formation in Magma
Award.AbstractNarration:
Magmas are generally composed of three main components, a melt, one or several types of minerals, and a vapor phase in the form of bubbles. The formation and growth of minerals (or crystals) and of the vapor phase (bubbles) exerts a major influence on the behavior of their host magmas because they modify the magma?s physical properties (e.g., viscosity/fluidity, volume) and influence its thermodynamic state (e.g. heat and mass distribution among phases), ultimately controlling what type of eruption (e.g. effusive vs. explosive) will occur. The formation of crystals and bubbles from the melt occurs via a process of spontaneous ?nucleation?, during which the crystal and vapor-forming components aggregate to a critical size. These nuclei then grow by further addition of components to the newly formed melt-crystal or melt-bubble interface. It is critical to understand the nucleation process in magmas because the initial number of nuclei controls the final distribution of crystals or bubbles. This proposal aims to better understand the formation of crystal and bubble nuclei via experimental and analytical approaches. The results could influence our understanding of nucleation theory, and experimental data could be implemented in predictive physical and numerical magma ascent and eruption models.

The energetics and kinetics of nucleation are increasingly well understood for glass ceramics, a class of engineered materials in which a glass hosts a high population density of nm-scale crystals. The development and characterization of industrial glass ceramics has stimulated technological developments in nanoanalysis and spectroscopic investigation of glasses, providing unprecedented opportunities for studying nucleation in naturally-occurring aluminosilicate melts. In its fundamental form, the Classical Nucleation Theory may be used to model experimental nucleation data for natural melts, but only if key assumptions concerning interfacial energy (for crystals) and surface tension (bubbles) are relaxed. Lack of firm understanding of these energy terms, operative at the nanometer scale and therefore elusive to conventional imaging techniques, is especially troubling because the theory stipulates that their influence over nucleation rate is profound. An additional complexity is that while nucleation in magma appears to occur homogeneously for crystals, thus involving just two phases, nucleation of bubbles may occur more typically by a heterogeneous process, involving energetic relationships among three phases. This project proposes to (1) experimentally investigate crystal and bubble nucleation in an intermediate (andesitic) and a silicic (rhyolite) melt, (2) revisit classical nucleation theory in the context of these natural magmas, (3) explore the spatial frontier (i.e., nanoscale) of incipient crystallization via cuttingedge analytical instruments presently available, and (4) perform a novel dynamic crystallization experiment to evaluate the influence of magma flow and shearing on crystal nucleation. The proposed effort to understand bubble and crystal nucleation kinetics hasfar-reaching implications for the field of physical volcanology, which is increasingly concerned with phase transformations occurring during magma ascent.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Investigating the fundamentals aspects of phase transformation (from melt to crystal, from liquid to vapor) in magmas in vital if we are to understand and predict their behavior and explosive potential as they rise towards the surface. During this award period, significant progress was made in our quest to better quantify and model nucleation, growth, and chemical characteristics of bubbles and crystals in magmas. Laboratory experiments of crystallization and vesiculation, coupled with careful analysis of crystal and bubble textures in natural products of eruptions yielded several crucial lessons outlined below:

(1)   The exsolution of volatiles through the process of bubble nucleation in magmas is likely responsible for controlling the fate of eruptions (explosive vs. mild or effusive). Contrary to our previous thinking, however, our results have shown that nucleation does not occur as a random, homogeneous process in the melt. It is enhanced by the presence of tiny microscopic iron-rich crystals. Without these crystals, nucleation is difficult and may be delayed. We show that the influence of these crystals can be accounted for by simple empirical models, and that measurements of bubble abundance (their numbers) in products of explosive eruptions (pumice, scoria) can be utilized to obtain direct, reliable information on magma ascent rates (Fig. 1).

 

(2)   The process of crystallization of magmas is also initiated by nucleation of a solid phase. Because the physical properties (e.g. fluidity, resistance to flow, eruptibility) of magmas depend on their crystal content, it is essential to understand and quantify how crystals nucleate and grow in a given period of time. Work performed during this project helped clarify the role of so-called ‘superheating’ of magmas – the process of bringing a magma to a temperature way above the point at which crystals are no longer stable – in controlling how many crystals will eventually nucleate once this magma is brought down to lower temperatures. It was shown that such superheating treatments influence how many crystals nucleated during cooling, and therefore that the structure of a melt cannot be neglected for phase transformation considerations.

 

(3)   The complex interactions that magmas undergo during their ascent to the surface can be recorded in crystals that grow and respond to environmental perturbations. This record can be accessed through the study of zoning, patterns that develop during initial crystal growth and are subsequently modified by diffusion of elements in the mineral. We showed that by examining different chemical elements in a single mineral, we can access different parts of its history in its host magma (e.g. Fig. 2). In particular, accessing the chemical signature of initial crystal growth allowed us to infer the source characteristics of Hawaiian magmas erupted at Kilauea volcano (Hawaii), and accessing the signature of chemical diffusion permitted us to extract the timescales of magma mixing prior to final ascent and eruption (also at Kilauea).

 

Those different but parallel findings have direct impacts on our capacity to quantify rates of phase transformation in magmas, and understand the timescales that are involved. The proposed efforts to understand bubble and crystal nucleation kinetics have far-reaching implications for the field of physical volcanology. Excel spreadsheets and Matlab scripts were shared with the community and distributed along with our publications to facilitate calculations of magma ascent/decompression rates from the texture of eruptive products. Undergraduate STEM students were recruited to participate in experimental and theory-development activities, promoting the scientific education of underrepresented student populations. The outcomes of this project have stimulated new collaborations with Singapore, UK, and other US-based universities, and formed the base for new PhD projects and research proposals that are underway.
